Graphical abstract Highly crystalline 2D covalent organic frameworks (COFs) are synthesized for high-performance lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), and an unprecedented 110,000 ultralong cycling stability with ∼100 % capacity retention at a high current density of 10,000 mA g−1 is demonstrated, signifying an important step in the advancements of next-generation LIBs. Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) with high energy and power densities are extensively applied in various fields, such as portable electronic devices and electric vehicles. Compared with traditional inorganic electrode materials, which confront the challenges of resource scarcity and restrained energy density, covalent organic frameworks (COFs) are attractive candidates as electrode materials for the next-generation LIBs. Herein, rational Schiff-base condensation of tetraphenyl-pphenylenediamine (TPPDA) and 5,12-bis(4-(5,5-dimethyl-1,3-dioxan-2-yl)phenyl)-5,12-dihydroquinolino[2,3-b]acridine-7,14-dione (QA-PCHO) yields a two-dimensional (2D) QT-COF as the cathode. 2D QT-COF features a high crystalline nature with kgm topology and hierarchically micro-/meso-porous structure, which can strengthen the stability of the chemical structure and promote the fast Li+ diffusion under large current densities. These merits make the QT-COF cathode exhibit 110,000 ultralong cycling stability with ∼100 % retention at 10,000 mA g−1 upon running for 150 days, exceeding all the thus far reported COF-based electrodes. Additionally, the combination of ex situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, in-situ Raman investigation, and theoretical calculation exhaustively unveils the ion storage mechanism and the rationale underlying the exceptional property of QT-COF. The present result offers an advanced COF with enormous potential as organic electrodes for LIBs, hopefully solving the challenges of ultrahigh cycling stability with superb capacity preservation at high current densities. Keywords 2D Covalent organic frameworks Highly crystalline Lithium-ion batteries Ultralong cycling stability Bipolar ion storage mechanism 1 Introduction Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), as one of the most indispensable energy-supply devices, have attracted continuous research interests all over the world [1–3]. In comparison with inorganic electrodes undergoing the traditional Li+ intercalation process, organic electrodes with relatively high specific capacity based on simple redox reactions can take place on a short timescale [4–6]. As a consequence, organic electrode materials as attractive candidates for the next-generation LIBs with high capacity and rapid charging property have received a wide range of attention [7–10]. However, small-molecule-based organic electrodes usually suffer from low cycling stability associated with their high solubility in organic electrolytes [11,12]. This results in the exploration of insoluble polymeric materials-based organic electrodes [13–15]. Organic polymers, which can be obtained by combining redox-active centers and aromatic frameworks with a certain degree of conjugation, have favorable lithiation ability, improved Li+ diffusion, and fast reaction dynamics, endowing them with good prospects as electrode materials in LIBs [16–19]. Nevertheless, the inhomogeneous dispersion and poor accessibility of active centers in the amorphous framework of traditional organic polymers impede the insertion/extraction of Li+ ions to a large extent. In addition, the polymers in an amorphous state always show undesirable stability at high current densities [20,21]. To deal with the above-mentioned restrictions, lots of efforts have been made to design and synthesize advanced organic polymers having prominent electrochemical properties. Covalent organic frameworks (COFs) composed of molecular building blocks via covalent bonding represent a novel type of porous crystalline polymeric materials and display great potential as promising electrode materials for LIBs because of their structural versatility, permanent porosity, π-conjugated frameworks, and large surface area [22–27]. Although many efforts have been devoted to using COFs as electrode materials for LIBs recently, there are still restrictions from the aspects of power density, rate property, and peculiar cycling stability, which is an essential criterion for developing practical COF electrodes for LIBs [28,29]. On the other hand, constructing COF electrode materials with ultralong cycling stability at high current densities is still extremely challenging due to the difficulty in controlling the easily collapsed crystalline and chemical structure, preserving the sufficient active site accessibility, and maintaining fast charge/discharge kinetics during harsh and long-term cycling [30–32]. It is worth noting that since the fabrication of the first LIB electrode from boronate ester-linked two-dimensional (2D) COF on carbon nanotube (CNT), which showed 85 % capacity retention after 700 cycles [33], great efforts have been made towards enhancing the cycling stability of COF electrode materials for LIBs. This leads to the fabrication of mesoporous crystalline polyarylimide-linked 2D COF-based LIBs electrode with 100 % capacity retention after 8000 cycles [10], imine-bonded TAPP-Pz-COF-40 %CNT electrode with 88 % capacity retention after 10,000 cycles [34], polyimide COF-JLU86 with 99.11 % capacity retention after 10,000 cycles [28], and thiazole-linked TAM-DMPZD-COF-S electrode with 92 % capacity retention after 50,000 cycles [35]. Obviously, such performance is still far from meeting the high demands of electrode materials for practical LIB applications in various fields with necessary high rate performance and, in particular, ultralong cycling stability, such as optoelectronics and energy storage. Investigations suggest that improving the thermal/chemical stability, enhancing the crystallinity, strengthening the linked skeleton, accelerating the reaction kinetics, and increasing the accessibility of redox-active sites of COFs are able to result in enhanced cycling stability of LIB electrodes [36–39]. It is, however, worth noting again that despite the above-mentioned attractive attributes, the elaborate preparation of COFs-based electrodes with remarkably ultralong cycling stability for LIBs through combining these strategies has not yet been achieved. In this work, a 2D covalent organic framework, QT-COF, is designed and fabricated from the condensation of tetraphenyl-pphenylenediamine (TPPDA) and 5,12-bis(4-(5,5-dimethyl-1,3-dioxan-2-yl)phenyl)-5,12-dihydroquinolino[2,3-b]acridine-7,14-dione (QA-PCHO). Powder X-ray diffraction and electron microscopy reveal its high crystalline nature with kgm topology and AA stacking mode. N2 sorption isotherm discloses its hierarchical structure with abundant micropores (1.3 nm) and mesopores (3.4 nm). This, in combination with its rich bipolar redox active moieties, including p-type active units (sp 3 N) with high redox potential and n-type units (carbonyl groups) with high theoretical specific capacity, endows this 2D QT-COF cathode with a specific capacity of 145 mA h g−1, an energy density of 390 W h kg−1, and a power density of 1352 W kg−1 at 200 mA g−1 along with remarkable rate capability (100 mA h g−1, 231 W h kg−1, and 23,760 W kg−1 at 10,000 mA g−1). In particular, this cathode exhibits 110,000 ultralong cycling stability with ∼100 % retention at a fast current density of 10,000 mA g−1 upon running for 150 days, exceeding all the thus far reported LIBs electrodes as exemplified by the highest cycles of 50,000 for cathodes [35] and 20,000 for anodes [40] (Table S1). The ex situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and in-situ Raman investigation as well as theoretical calculations were conducted to unveil the ion storage mechanism and the rationale underlying its exceptional property, disclosing a 6 PF6 −/4 Li+ redox mechanism on each asymmetric unit and the key roles of sufficiently exposed redox active moieties with high density and robust linked skeleton in enhancing the electrochemical performance of QT-COF. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Acetone (99.5 %), ethanol (EtOH, 99.7 %), methanol (MeOH, 99.7 %), tetrahydrofuran (THF, 99.6 %), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 99.5 %), chloroform (99.0 %), n-butylalcohol (n-BuOH, 99.8 %), orthodichlorobenzene (o-DCB, 99.0 %), and N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP, 98.0 %) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Poly(1,1-difluoroethylene) (PVDF) and electrolyte of 1.0 M lithium hexafluorophosphate (LiPF6) in ethylene carbonate (EC)/ethyl methyl carbonate (EMC) (3:7, v/v) were provided by Canrd Technology Co., Ltd. QA-PCHO was prepared using the published procedures [41], Fig. S1. TPPDA was purchased from Bide Pharmatech Ltd. 2.2 Synthesis of QT-COF The synthesis of QT-COF was conducted in a 10 mL Pyrex tube charged with QA-PCHO (20.8 mg, 0.03 mmol), TPPDA (7.1 mg, 0.015 mmol), and a 1:4 (v/v) mixture of o-dichlorobenzene (0.2 mL) and n-butanol (0.8 mL) containing 6 M acetic acid (0.1 mL). The mixture was subjected to 30-minute sonication for homogenization, followed by three freeze-pump-thaw cycles under liquid N2 to ensure oxygen-free condition. The sealed reactor was heated at 120 °C for 5 days, producing a reddish-brown precipitate. The crude product was isolated by centrifugation and purified through sequential washing with DMF and acetone, followed by vacuum drying at 80 °C overnight to afford QT-COF as a crystalline powder (18.7 mg, 67.1 % yield). 2.3 Electrochemical measurements The electrochemical property of QT-COF for LIBs was experimentally examined by assembling QT-COF cathode into Li-ion coin cells assembled in an Ar-filled glove box using Li foil as the counter electrode. The electrolyte of 1.0 M LiPF6 in EC/EMC (3:7, v/v) was used during the electrochemical tests. To prepare working electrode, a homogeneous slurry containing 50 wt% active material, 40 wt% Ketjenblack conductive additive, and 10 wt% PVDF binder distributed in NMP was uniformly coated onto aluminum foil using a doctor blade, followed by drying at 100 °C under vacuum for 24 h. The mass loading of active material was approximately 0.8 mg cm−2. The cell configuration consisted of Li foil counter electrode, 1 M LiPF6 in EC/EMC (3:7 v/v) electrolyte, and Celgard 2400 separator. A galvanostatic charge/discharge test was performed within 1.2–4.3 V vs. Li+/Li using a LAND 2001A battery testing system (Wuhan, China). Cyclic voltammetry (CV) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) tests were conducted on a CHI 660E electrochemical workstation (Shanghai, China). For full-cell evaluation, pre-cycled QT-COF cathode (500 mA g−1 for 20 cycles) and graphene anode were paired with the same 1 M LiPF6 in EC/EMC electrolyte. The full cell was operated within 0.7–3.8 V with specific capacity calculations based on the cathode material mass. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization First, as illustrated in Scheme 1 , the solvothermal reaction between TPPDA and QA-PCHO under the catalysis of acetic acid affords QT-COF. The framework of QT-COF possesses rich redox active moieties of carbonyl groups and sp 3 N (C–N groups), enabling a theoretical capacity of 185 mA h g−1. QT-COF was characterized by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) and solid-state 13C cross-polarization magic angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (13C CP/MAS NMR) spectroscopy. The FT-IR spectrum of QT-COF shows intense vibration bands at 1709, 1325, and 1631 cm−1, corresponding to the C=O groups of QA-PCHO, the C–N units of TPPDA, and the characteristic C=N units, respectively, whereas the vibrational peaks at 2850–2960 and 3200–3500 cm−1 corresponding to the starting aliphatic stretching bands in QA-PCHO and N–H stretching bands in TPPDA get disappeared [41,42], proving the successful construction of fully imide skeleton of QT-COF (Fig. 1 a). In the solid-state 13C CP/MAS NMR spectrum of QT-COF, a characteristic resonance signal at 158 ppm for carbon of imine moiety is detected, also illustrating the formation of imine linkage via the Schiff-base condensation reaction between TPPDA and QA-PCHO to yield QT-COF (Fig. 1b) [43]. Furthermore, the resolved N 1s XPS result exhibits three peaks at 399.4, 400.0, and 400.5 eV due to C=N in the imine bond, C–N in the TPPDA, and C–N in the QA-PCHO, respectively, further demonstrating the generation of imine linkage (Fig. S2) [44,45]. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) test, along with theoretical simulation and Pawley refinement, was applied to reveal the crystal structure of QT-COF. The PXRD pattern of QT-COF displays a series of peaks at 1.72°, 2.92°, 3.40°, 4.52°, 5.10°, 6.13°, and 6.80°, corresponding to (1 0 0), (2 1 0), (2 0 0), (3 1 0), (3 0 0), (4 1 0), and (4 0 0) planes, respectively, revealing its high crystalline nature. The pattern matches well with the simulated one of the eclipsed AA stacked model, in good conformity with QT-COF with kgm lattice crystallized in P 321 space group (a = b = 59.0185 Å, c = 3.5172 Å, α = β = 90°, and γ = 120°) with convergent R p factor of 3.25 % and R wp factor of 4.32 % (Fig. 1c, d, Fig. S3, and Table S2). The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were recorded at 77 K to confirm the kgm topology and permanent porosity of QT-COF. As seen in Fig. 1(e) and Fig. S4, QT-COF displays a typical type I (b) curve, yielding a large Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of 735 m2 g−1 and a high pore volume of 1.19 cm3 g−1, very close to the theoretical value of 1.14 cm3 g−1 on the basis of structural characterization result. The significant rise in the low-pressure range (P/P 0 < 0.1) and obvious adsorption platform in the medium pressure range demonstrate the hierarchically microporous and narrow mesoporous configuration of QT-COF. The high surface area and wide pore size range of QT-COF afford sufficient active site exposure, and the distinctive dual-pore feature not only facilitates the ion diffusion but also elevates the utilization ratio of the redox active sites. Furthermore, the distribution of pore size concentrated at about 1.3 and 3.4 nm can be found in the inset of Fig. 1(e). The experimentally revealed micropore and mesopore sizes are in good agreement with the theoretical values predicted by the modeled AA stacking structure with kgm topology. In addition, as shown in Fig. 1(f, g) and Fig. S5, QT-COF displays a peony-like morphology assembled from many rod-like particles in the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images. The distinct lattice fringes with a spacing of 3.3 nm in the high-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) image of QT-COF, attributable to its (100) facet, further certify its high crystalline structure nature (Fig. 1h). Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) analysis demonstrates that C, N, and O elements are uniformly dispersed over the porous structure of QT-COF (Fig. 1i). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) reveals that QT-COF does not decompose until 463 °C, indicating its high thermal stability (Fig. S6). After immersing QT-COF in a series of solvents including NMP, acetone, DMF, THF, H2O, EtOH, and electrolyte at room temperature for 7 days, the PXRD patterns of the recovered QT-COF samples remain almost unchanged from that of the pristine sample (Fig. S7), suggesting the excellent maintenance of crystallinity under these conditions. The FT-IR spectra of the treated QT-COF samples also prove the well-maintained imine-linked skeletons (Fig. S8). These results disclose the preeminent chemical stability of QT-COF. 3.2 Electrochemical performance Inspired by the kgm topology with well-ordered and rich micropores and mesopores, high crystallinity, excellent stability, and especially the bipolar redox active moieties (carbonyl groups and C–N groups), QT-COF is certainly an attractive organic electrode material for LIBs (Fig. S9). CV tests of QT-COF were performed in the coin cells at 0.2 mV s−1 in a potential range from 1.2 to 4.3 V (Fig. S10). In the collected CV profiles, four pairs of redox peaks at 2.35/1.86, 3.47/2.67, 3.87/3.49, and 4.18/3.97 V vs. Li+/Li were observed, corresponding to the redox reactions of C=O in QA-PCHO as well as C–N in TPPDA and QA-PCHO. In addition, compared with QT-COF, both QA-PCHO and TPPDA electrodes show relatively poor reversibility of the redox reactions due to the dissolution of QA-PCHO and TPPDA molecules in the electrolyte (Figs. S11 and S12). The galvanostatic discharge/charge curves of QT-COF were recorded at various current densities of 500, 1000, 2000, 5000, 7000, and 10,000 mA g−1 (Fig. 2 a, b, and Fig. S13). As expected, QT-COF shows superior rate performance. Along with the increase in the current density, the specific capacities of QT-COF cells are 175, 143, 129, 117, 111, and 100 mA h g−1 at 500, 1000, 2000, 5000, 7000, and 10,000 mA g−1, respectively, and the largest utilization of active site amounts to 94.6 %. In particular, when the current density reduces back to 500 mA g−1, a specific capacity of 167 mA h g−1 is recovered, revealing the superior reversible nature of the QT-COF electrode. Notably, the QT-COF cathode can achieve a high energy density of 231 W h kg−1 even at a large current density of 10,000 mA g−1, corresponding to a power density of 23,760 W kg−1 with a complete charge or discharge time of 35 s. In addition, the long-term cycling stability (execution time of about 150 days) of QT-COF was investigated at 10,000 mA g−1. After initial electrochemical activation process, which is universally needed for carbon-based organic electrodes, QT-COF keeps a large capacity of 142 mA h g−1 for 110,000 cycles throughout the whole stability test process and almost no capacity decay can be found, demonstrating its superior ultralong cycling and structural stability (Fig. 2c). Additionally, this QT-COF still maintained good cycling stability at a relatively low current density of 1000 mA g−1 for 5000 cycles (Fig. S14). Such superior cycling stability of QT-COF could be attributed to the combination of its superior thermal/chemical stability, high crystallinity, stable linked skeleton, and accelerated reaction kinetics. Notably, the cycling stability of QT-COF is far superior to all the electrode materials, including both inorganic and organic ones for LIBs reported thus far (Fig. 2d and Table S1). The coulomb efficiency (CE) of the QT-COF cathode was tested to commendably reveal the cycling efficiency. The CE of QT-COF is stabilized at ∼100 % for over 110,000 cycles. In contrast, obvious capacity loss and unsatisfactory CE were observed for both QA-PCHO and TPPDA during 40,000 continuous cycles at a current density of 10,000 mA g−1 due to their shuttle effect (Fig. S15). To assess the scalability of QT-COF, the rate performance of QT-COF with higher loadings of 2.6, 3.1, and 4.1 mg cm−2 has been tested. As seen in Fig. S16, these electrodes show similar specific capacities and rate performance to those of electrodes with a mass loading of 0.8 mg cm−2, revealing their great application potential. Additionally, the Li-ion coin cells of QT-COF-, QA-PCHO-, and TPPDA-based cathodes after cycling tests were disassembled. As shown in Fig. S17, in contrast to the separators of the cycled QA-PCHO- and TPPDA-based cells showing obvious color change in comparison with the original separators, the separator of the cycled QT-COF-based cell exhibits almost no color change, indicating the good stability of the QT-COF electrode in the electrolyte over the whole cycling test. Meanwhile, the PXRD pattern, XPS spectra, FT-IR spectra, SEM images, and TEM images of the cycled QT-COF sample indicate the robust frame structure, unchanged chemical state, well-preserved initial imine skeleton, peony-like morphology, and high crystalline structure of QT-COF after cycling (Figs. S18–S22). The extraordinary ultralong cycling stability of the QT-COF reveals the great potential of implementing this new COF material into a practical cathode for LIBs. Additionally, the ion diffusion coefficient in the QT-COF-based cells was examined using galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) (Fig. 2e) [46], giving an ion diffusion coefficient of 10−10 cm2 s−1 due to its unique hierarchical structure with rich micropores and mesopores, much larger than traditional inorganic and organic materials-based cathodes (Fig. S23). 3.3 Electrochemical mechanism The EIS measurements for QT-COF were conducted to probe the electrode kinetics during QT-COF-based Li-ion coin cells operating. As shown in the Nyquist plots (Fig. S24 and Table S3), the QT-COF-based coin cell possesses a charge transfer resistance (R ct) as low as 197.2 Ω, confirming its rapid reaction dynamics. Towards understanding the outstanding rate performance and large utilization of active sites of the QT-COF cathode, a series of CV tests were conducted at various scan speeds of 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, 1.0, and 1.2 mV s−1. As shown in Fig. 3 (a), the peak current of the QT-COF electrode has no linear relationship with the square root of the scan rate, indicating the occurrence of both faradaic and non-faradaic processes under the ion storage process [47]. According to Eq. (1) (1) l o g ( i ) = l o g ( a ) + b l o g ( v ) where i represents the peak current, v represents the sweep rate, and a and b are tunable parameters [48,49]. The values of b for O1, O2, O3, and O4 were determined as 0.996, 0.974, 0.938, and 0.976, while the values of b for R1, R2, R3, and R4 were determined as 0.970, 0.957, 0.942, and 0.995 (Fig. 3b), revealing the pseudocapacitive-controlled course of the QT-COF cathode with rapid dynamics for Li+ and PF6 − storage. This result is certainly associated with the unblocked ion diffusion in the ordered hierarchical channels and highly accessible dual redox active moieties (such as C=O and C–N) in QT-COF with excellent electrical conductivity. To quantitatively divide the diffusion and surface capacitive contributions of the total capacity produced by the QT-COF-based Li-ion coin cell, Trasatti analysis was performed. The surface capacitive contribution ratio is 86 % at 0.4 mV s−1 for the QT-COF electrode, which progressively rises to 95 % at 1.2 mV s−1 (Fig. 3c and Fig. S25), implying that the Li-ion storage in QT-COF is synergistically limited by diffusive and surface capacitive characteristics, with the dominance of surface capacitive-limited process for achieving fast Li+ transport. This indicates the mainly surface capacitive effect-controlled ion storage of the QT-COF electrode, resulting in fast ion diffusion dynamics and high rate performance. To probe the Li+ and PF6 − ion storage mechanism on the dual redox-active moieties during the cycling process, ex situ high-resolution XPS spectra at various charged and discharged states were collected to investigate the composition change in the QT-COF electrode (Fig. 3d–f). Peaks at 399.4, 400.5, and 400.0 eV in the high-resolution N 1s XPS spectrum of pristine QT-COF belong to imine bond (C=N), C–N (N sp 3) in QA, and C–N (sp 3 N) in TPPDA, respectively [44,45]. The O 1s XPS spectrum of pristine QT-COF contains only one peak at 532.3 eV that can be assigned to the C=O [50]. Upon being charged to 4.3 V, the peak for C–N gets reduced due to the chemical adsorption of PF6 − on the C–N bonds, while a new peak at 400.8 eV attributed to N–PF6 − appears [51]. The intensity of the N–PF6 − peak gradually decreases and the C–N peak recovers during the subsequent discharge process, disclosing the reversible chemical adsorption and desorption processes of PF6 − ions in the QT-COF. Meanwhile, under the discharging process, another peak due to the O–Li bond at 536.5 eV in the O 1s XPS spectrum of pristine QT-COF gradually emerges [52]. The intensity change of the peak in the O 1s XPS spectrum also reveals the reversible Li+ storage course in the QT-COF. Encouraged by the remarkable property of the QT-COF cathode in half batteries, a Li-ion full cell was assembled by using graphite as an anode and QT-COF as a cathode. Impressively, the QT-COF//graphite full battery exhibits a capacity of 91 mA h g−1 at 5000 mA g−1 with almost no capacity loss even after 8000 cycles, demonstrating the great promise of QT-COF for LIB applications (Fig. 3g, h and Fig. S26). Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were implemented to identify the continuous structural evolution of a QT-COF unit containing one QA group and one TPPDA group during carrier insertion and extraction processes at the level of M06-2X/6-311G(d) [53–55]. To determine the exact accommodation redox-active sites of Li+ and PF6 − ions in QT-COF, the molecular electrostatic potential (MESP) method was used to conjecture the electrophilic and nucleophilic reaction sites on the asymmetric group of QT-COF with positive region in red and negative region in blue. QT-COF undergoes the oxidation reaction under the original charging process by losing two electrons to yield [QT]2+, which is willing to absorb two negative PF6 − ions from the electrolyte, generating [QT]2+ ∙ 2PF6 − (Fig. 4 a and b). Then, [QT]2+ ∙ 2PF6 − experiences further oxidation reaction by losing another four electrons to finish charging, yielding [QT]6+ ∙ 2PF6 − (Fig. 4c). Subsequently, [QT]6+ ∙ 2PF6 − with positive red region mainly concentrated at sp 3 N atoms in the QA moiety adsorbs another four negative PF6 − to form [QT]6+ ∙ 6PF6 − to maintain electric neutrality (Fig. 4d). Under the discharging course, [QT]6+ goes through the first reduction reaction to reach the neutral state by accepting six electrons and simultaneously extracting the adsorbed PF6 − ions. Further reducing the neutral QT by accepting four electrons forms the fully reduced state of [QT]4− (Fig. 4e). The MESP value of the four C=O in QA units of [QT]4− is more negative (the blue region), indicating its higher electronegativity, resulting in such a result that the four C=O groups are highly accessible for the electrophilic Li+ ions. As a consequence, the [QT]4− unit is willing to adsorb four positive Li+ ions on the C=O sites to form [QT]4− ∙ 4Li+ at this stage (Fig. 4f). The bandgap calculations were also conducted. As displayed in Fig. 5 (a–c), the pristine QT-COF has a small bandgap of 1.07 eV, which would be further reduced to approximately 0 eV after combining with Li+ or PF6 − ions, demonstrating its superior conductivity. As shown in Fig. 5(d), the electron and PF6 − ion diffusion during charging/discharging processes between [QT] and [QT]6+ ∙ 6PF6 − via the intermediate [QT]2+ ∙ 2PF6 − corresponds to the p-type redox active sites of QA and TPPDA moieties, while the electron and Li+ ion diffusion during the charging/discharging processes between [QT] and [QT]4− ∙ 4Li+ is attributed to the n-type redox active sites of the QA moiety. These observations match well with the XPS results, indicating that the charging and discharging processes on the QT-COF cathode comply with a bipolar redox mechanism. In addition, the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) were calculated since the redox performances of the QT-COF are closely related to the electronic structure of the QT-COF skeleton (Fig. S27). According to the calculation result, all the gaps between HOMO and LUMO of QT-COF at various redox states are smaller than those for corresponding neutral materials, implying the high electrical conductivity and improved reaction kinetics on the QT-COF electrode. This, in turn, will elevate the rate properties. On the basis of the analysis of differential charge density, the charge shifts from the PF6 − ions to the QA and TPPDA sites once the QT unit adsorbs PF6 − ions (Fig. S28a), while the charge transfers to the Li+ from the QA unit after Li+ ion adsorption in QT-COF (Fig. S28b), demonstrating the strong electronic interaction between PF6 −/Li+ and QA, TPPDA groups [56]. The large binding energies of PF6 −/Li+ in QT unit can also be observed from Fig. 5(d). For the purpose of understanding the Li-ion storage of the QT-COF electrode during the electrochemical process, the total binding energies of QT at various oxidation states during the lithiation process were calculated by DFT calculations (Fig. 5e). The calculated total energy for [QT]6+ ∙ 6PF6 − is −2.741 × 10−5 eV, which increases to −1.781 × 10−5 eV for [QT]2+ ∙ 2PF6 − and −1.206 × 10−5 eV for QT, attributable to the large discharge potential zone of 4.2–3.2 and 3.2–2.1 V, respectively, due to the p-type redox process in QA and TPPDA units. The calculated total energy of [QT]4− ∙ 4Li+ drops to −1.214 × 10−5 eV, attributable to the small discharge potential zone of 2.1–1.2 V, due to the n-type redox process in QA units. According to the above results, the C=O groups and sp 3 N (C–N groups) in QT-COF are able to conduct chemical adsorption/desorption of Li+/PF6 − effectively. To further examine the structural stability and ion storage mechanism of the QT-COF cathode under the electrochemical operating process, in situ Raman spectra under charging and discharging processes were collected (Fig. 6 a–c). As seen, the intensities of the peaks at 1588 and 1620 cm−1 due to the vibrations of –CH=N– and C=O, respectively, remain almost unchanged under the charging process. Under the discharging process, the intensity of the peak corresponding to C=O gets gradually weakened and finally completely disappears due to the formation of O–Li bond through the chemical adsorption of Li+ on the C=O bond, while the intensity of the peak due to –CH=N– still exhibits a negligible change. These results reveal the high stability of the –CH=N– unit in the QT-COF cathode during the electrochemical operating process. 4 Conclusions In summary, a highly crystalline and kgm topological 2D covalent organic framework (QT-COF) has been successfully fabricated by using a rationally designed solvothermal synthetic method. Dual redox active sites, carbonyl groups and sp 3 N (C–N groups), and a unique hierarchical structure with ordered triangular micropores and hexagonal mesopores are observed in QT-COF. Comprehensive electrochemical investigations demonstrate that QT-COF-based LIBs show excellent performance, in particular an extraordinary 110,000 ultralong cycling stability with ∼100 % retention at a high current density of 10,000 mA g−1. These results signify an enormous advancement over formerly published COFs, particularly ultralong cycling stability at high current densities. The sufficiently exposed redox active moieties with high density and robust linked skeleton are revealed as crucial factors that enhance the electrochemical performance. This work provides a prospective method to address the challenges of ultralong cycling stability with superb capacity preservation at high current densities, which symbolizes an important step in the advancement of LIBs. coredata.dc:description: Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) with high energy and power densities are extensively applied in various fields, such as portable electronic devices and electric vehicles. Compared with traditional inorganic electrode materials, which confront the challenges of resource scarcity and restrained energy density, covalent organic frameworks (COFs) are attractive candidates as electrode materials for the next-generation LIBs. Herein, rational Schiff-base condensation of tetraphenyl-pphenylenediamine (TPPDA) and 5,12-bis(4-(5,5-dimethyl-1,3-dioxan-2-yl)phenyl)-5,12-dihydroquinolino[2,3-b]acridine-7,14-dione (QA-PCHO) yields a two-dimensional (2D) QT-COF as the cathode. 2D QT-COF features a high crystalline nature with kgm topology and hierarchically micro-/meso-porous structure, which can strengthen the stability of the chemical structure and promote the fast Li+ diffusion under large current densities. These merits make the QT-COF cathode exhibit 110,000 ultralong cycling stability with ∼100 % retention at 10,000 mA g−1 upon running for 150 days, exceeding all the thus far reported COF-based electrodes. Additionally, the combination of ex situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, in-situ Raman investigation, and theoretical calculation exhaustively unveils the ion storage mechanism and the rationale underlying the exceptional property of QT-COF. The present result offers an advanced COF with enormous potential as organic electrodes for LIBs, hopefully solving the challenges of ultrahigh cycling stability with superb capacity preservation at high current densities.
